Our study considered the entire range of the Mexican long-nosed bat ( L. nivalis) from central Mexico to the south-western United States (Top left: 43.520°, −116.754°; Down right: 15.645°, −95.079°). This bat migrates every spring following the blooming events of paniculated agaves
26 . Thus, we selected paniculate agaves occurring within the bat’s range and documented either in the bat’s diet
47 or to be blooming when the bat was present in a particular area
27, 48– 50 .
